awd_titl_txt: Evolution of neural induction and dorsal-ventral axis specification: BMP network involvement in annelids
awd_abstract_narration:
Many animals have a centralized nervous system (CNS) where neural cells (neurons) are clustered together; an example is the brain and spinal cord of humans. This arrangement of neurons is thought to provide better integration and more sophisticated processing of information, but a thorough understanding of how complex CNSs arose in different animal groups and how these CNSs compare with one another is lacking. This project addresses these questions by examining CNS development in a very understudied group of animals, the annelid worms. Annelids are important for studies of neural development because they have CNSs with thousands of neurons that easily regenerate, unlike other animal CNSs that either do not regenerate well (e.g. humans) or do not have many neurons in their CNS.  This project will provide a better understanding of how a complex CNS can form and will develop several techniques as resources for the scientific community, including CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing in the annelid Capitella teleta. This project also will support and train undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow. Finally, the findings and techniques developed in this project will be used to 1) augment undergraduate projects in a developmental biology course, 2) improve current outreach efforts with the Girls, Inc. Eureka summer program to engage local junior-high girls in STEM activities, and 3) develop, implement, and asses a new teaching module for local high school students and teachers that is designed to promote an appreciation of CNS diversity and a better understanding of how animal diversity arose.

A key question concerning animal evolution is how CNSs evolved and contributed to organismal diversity. In many animals with a CNS, a whole region of the ectoderm acquires the potential to become neural as part of dorsal-ventral (D-V) axis specification. In vertebrates and insects, Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP) signaling plays an important role in both processes. This raises the question of whether or not the last common ancestor of deuterostomes and protostomes had a CNS and whether neural induction was linked to D-V axis specification in this animal. To test these hypotheses, data is needed from additional taxa, especially spiralians, one of two main protostome groups. This project will test these hypotheses by investigating the role of BMP signaling in D-V axis and CNS fate specification in the spiralian annelid Capitella teleta. Project aims are: 1) Determine the degree of conservation of BMP pathway components in C. teleta by characterizing their expression dynamics using in situ hybridization and immunohistochemistry, 2) Assess the ancestral role of BMP signaling through gain- and loss-of-function experiments in C. teleta utilizing BMP protein and dorsomorphin, and 3) Assess the ancestral role of the BMP antagonist Chordin by analyzing function in C. teleta through CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing and morpholino knockdown. By studying the function of BMP signaling during development of a spiralian annelid, this work will significantly contribute to our understanding of CNS evolution and the involvement of the BMP signaling network in D-V axis specification and CNS formation in the ancestral bilaterian.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Nervous systems are a critical animal innovation. The evolution of centralized nervous systems (e.g., brains and nerve cords) shifted information processing from more localized networks to ones that centralized and integrated multiple inputs and outputs, thus enabling a wide range of behaviors and adaptations. Because of this project, we demonstrated that the developmental mechanisms used to build an annelid central nervous system are different from those found in vertebrates (including humans) and insects, suggesting that centralized nervous systems may have evolved independently in at least annelids. This project resulted in adaptation of multiple technologies for use in an annelid developmental model including CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, in situ hybridization chain reaction and manipulation of receptor-mediated cell signaling via a dominant-negative receptor. Our results have shifted our understanding of nervous system evolution, which has wide-reaching implications for how information can be processed, which should benefit the disciplines of evolutionary developmental biology, developmental biology and neuroscience.

We tested the hypothesis that the last common ancestor of Bilateria (and Spiralia) had a centralized nervous system (CNS) that was delimited along its dorsal-ventral axis. In brief, we characterized expression of many components of the BMP signaling pathway from early cleavage to late larval stages in the annelid Capitella teleta. We assessed function of BMP signaling during formation of the central nervous system (brain + ventral nerve cord) and dorsal-ventral axis using a combination of drugs (e.g., dorsomorphin), soaking in recombinant BMP4 protein and injection of dominant-negative (truncated) Cte-BMPR1::Venus mRNA, and phospho-SMAD1/5/8 immunohistochemistry and western blot analysis. We examined function of a putative BMP antagonist, Cte-Chordin-like, by CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, and we developed in situ hybridization chain reaction (HCR) to examine expression of different neural genes in C. teleta after manipulation of BMP signaling. We found that in the annelid Capitella teleta (Spiralia), neither formation of CNS nor the dorsal-ventral axis relies on the interplay between BMP ligands and BMP antagonists, as is the case in vertebrates (Deuterostomia) and insects (Ecdysozoa). Instead, we found evidence that BMP signaling helps establish blastomere identity across the four quadrants of the C. teleta embryo (A, B, C and D). Taken together, our results suggest a more complicated evolutionary scenario for CNSs across animals.

Broader impacts: This project provided professional training and mentorship in scientific research and multiple presentation opportunities for one postdoctoral fellow, four master's students, three PhD students and over 10 undergraduate students. Five of the seven graduate students have finished their advanced degree and are now either carrying out postdocs in developmental biology or have jobs in STEM fields. The postdoctoral fellow funded by this project is now in a tenure-track position at a university with her own research lab. This project provided training in anti-racist practices and activities centered around making science more welcoming and inclusive to all. The results from this project resulted in one publication in Developmental Biology and two manuscripts that are in the process of being submitted. The project was also the basis for two master's theses and chapters in the dissertations of two PhD students and one master's student that are published. Finally, work from this project will be included in a third dissertation of a current PhD student.

This project also provided hand-on activities in neuroscience, developmental biology and evolutionary developmental biology for over 80 local, inner-city, school-age children (ages 5-13), a majority BIPOC and female-identifying, and over 40 college undergraduates. We initiated two new collaborations with local schools. We designed a set of activities (six weeks total) around C. teleta nervous system development for use with 4th-6th graders and 7th-9th graders; however, these were cancelled due to the Covid-19 pandemic. A second collaboration with Recreation Worcester was initiated, and the PI and lab members ran a virtual, after-school, several-week-long program engaging five to 11-year-old children in fun activities to learn about nervous systems and the diversity of nervous systems across Metazoa. We also developed and ran yearly summer workshops with the Girls Inc. Eureka! program to expose middle school girls to developmental biology, nervous system diversity and scientific research using C. teleta and freshwater plankton samples collected from a neighboring lake. Finally, a new lab module using C. teleta to study body plan evolution was developed and implemented in an upper-level Developmental Biology course taught by the PI at Clark University. In summary, this project provided mentoring and experiences to a wide range of people including those in grade school, middle school and college and those at graduate and post-graduate levels.
